characters: BETWEEN ANDERSON / LISA AT THE JUDICIAL CENTER
AND MOTHER OF GOD DOES IT HURT

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUBURBIA DAY
dialogues.text: Morning in America.  Just look at it.  America in the midfifties, the suburban landscape stretching endlessly i the sun drenched distance.  White house upon white house. Emerald lawns, glistening with dew. In each driveway, a big Chevy, or a Ford, muscled with ch long tailfins that taper like the fins on rocket ships. Kids burst out of the houses, and zoom down sidewalks on trikes.  Mothers in bright dresses stand in doorways, watching.  The smiling mothers wave to one another, then back into their houses. Dogs bark, birds sing in trees of just the right height, boys and girls laugh and ring the bells on their trikes. is a delicious world, where dogs and birds and children a safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A family room with all the trappings of the era: a flagst fireplace, a console TV, a man's leatherette Barca-Lounge a pipe stand holding two pipes on a nearby table, boxes o children's games neatly stacked on a wall shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young mother, CAROL, her hair -in a pony-tail, stands a picture window in a corner of the family room, staring mi at the scene outside.

dialogues.speaker: A LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: A little girl bounces a red ball on the sidewalk.  The ba gets away from her, and rolls into the street. At the same moment, a two-toned CHEVY, lush and huge, rou the corner. The girl sees the car coming, but still goes after the ba

dialogues.speaker: THE FAMILY ROOM
dialogues.text: Carol sees what is about to happen -- but she doesn't cry out, or bang on the window, or run for the front door.  S watches.  And smiles a little.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: The girl careens gleefully into the middle of the street.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CHEVY
dialogues.text: The driver -- a man in a loose fitting dark green suit, w shirt, thin brown tie -- sits behind the steering wheel o the car. Disturbingly, the man's hands are not on the steering whe Not only that, he is holding the morning newspaper up in front of him, reading, oblivious to the scene before him. Through the windshield, we see the little girl in the roa in front of him, going for her ball. CAROL Watches, her smile in place.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: The little girl picks up her red ball, as the Chevy bears down on her.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CHEVY
dialogues.text: An alarm suddenly CHIRPS.  The car automatically brakes t halt.  The man looks around the edge of his paper to see what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET
dialogues.text: The car has stopped, inches from the girl. The girl giggles as, the man in the car gives her a big w She waves, then runs back to the sidewalk with her red ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man goes back to his newspaper, and the car, entirely its own, starts up again.  The car rounds a corner, and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Carol turns away from the window.  She startles when she sees her husband, JOHNNY, is there behind her.  He is in pajamas.  How long has he been there, watching her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gruff) Why'd you let me sleep so long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Saturday, Johnny, you always -- (beat) Why are you staring at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a step toward her.  He stands there, his thick b hair tousled with sleep, scratching his stubbled jaw, considering her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm unhappy that you let me sleep so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes another step toward her.  She doesn't move a mus A little BOY suddenly enters the room.  Johnny turns, loo at his son, looks back over his shoulder at his wife.  Th without a word, he begins to walk out of the room.  On hi way out, Johnny's eyes flick to Carol's sewing basket, wh sits beside a sewing machine.  It is not the sewing that caught his attention, but a large pair of garment SCISSOR which lie across a fold of colored cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny stands on the front porch, scratching.  He walks d his front walk, and bends over to pick up the newspaper. Carol stands in the doorway, watching him. A SHADOW slides over Johnny, cast from above.  The air fi with the piercing WHINE of an engine.  Johnny looks up, alarmed. In the sky above him, just beyond the tips of the suburba trees, is a black PRECRIME POLICE HOVERCRAFT. The children, the mothers, Carol in the doorway -- everyo freezes in place, as Johnny is cast into an inexplicable drama. Racing SOUNDLESSLY down the street toward him, are SLEEK TECHNOLOGICAL MARVELS, lethal and efficient looking -- th seem to be cars -- but they are so different from the fat Fords and Chevies in the driveways that it is hard for us process them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helmeted police with mirrored visors erupt out of the car More police drop from the hovercraft in harnesses.  Their uniforms are black, seem actually to absorb light.  Their left hands are bare, their right hands are encased in som sort of complicated glove.

dialogues.speaker: ON
dialogues.text: The glove is a weapon of some kind, the elongated index f ending in an open barrel. Clearly, this is not, as it first seemed, the past -- not America in the 1950's.  It is the neo-past, the retro wor of America 2040, where the familiar of yesterday is intermeshed with hypertechnology. And all of that hypertechnology is focused on JOHNNY, as makes a run for the house, sheets of newspaper scattering behind him.  He bursts up the front porch, shoving Carol of the way. Eight Precrime police officers assemble in the yard. From backpack, one of them quickly removes an instrument with handle grip and an ovoid screen.  It is a holographic sca He activates it, scans the OFFICER in front of him, and a IDENTICAL POLICE OFFICER takes three-dimensional form. The two real officers circle the house, repeating the man a dozen times. In less than a minute, a decoy force of men -- three dimensional, standing in place, but shifting and turning like living beings -- has been created.  An overwhelming police deterrent presence has been established.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The Precrime police overwhelm the interior of the house, too.  It is impossible to tell which officers are real, a which are scanned holographs.  The juxtaposition of the futuristic cops in a 1950's style house is disorienting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny, in his pajamas, crouches beneath a rack full of h wife's dresses.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Two OFFICERS, standing back-to-back, hold their gloved ha out in front of them, palm out.  When the first officer p his palm toward a door at the end of the hallway, his glo BEEPS softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer looks at his PALM.  A red thermal IMAGE appea on a small flexible screen -- the heat outline of a crouc man.  The first officer flicks his helmeted head to the s officer.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The room is packed with police -- how many are real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny squirms, his pajamas saturated with sweat.  He cal out through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every OFFICER in the room lifts his gloved hand and point his index barrel at the closet door.  The effect is deepl accusatory. An OFFICER speaks, his VOICE electronically manipulated t be as menacing as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come out of the closet on your hands and knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing happens.  Two officers aim their barrels at the perimeter of the door.  In repeated, small SONIC BLASTS, closet door is blown off of its frame, revealing Johnny a the dresses. Johnny starts to rise, and BAM, a section of floorboards blasted away beneath his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands and knees!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny trips among the splintered floorboards, and drops. He stays on his hands and knees, and approaches.  He lift his head and looks up at the officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another OFFICER 2 bends down with a DEVICE -- the words "IdentiScan" on its side -- and blips a red laser light  into each of Johnny's, eyes, reading his irises.  The  officer nods affirmatively to the other officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POSITIVE FOR JOHN PALMER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Johnny) John Palmer, if you were being arrested for any other crime, I would now read you your rights. (beat) But you are under arrest for the future murderer of your wife, Carol Palmer.  You have no rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny, on his hands and knees, goes limp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the background, Johnny is guided into a Precrime polic vehicle as the neighbors look on.  Carol and her son stan in the doorway, stunned. TWO OFFICERS remove their helmets.  The first man is tall sandy-haired, good eyes, deeply blue; This is PAUL ANDERS late thirties, Director of the Precrime Division, Washing D.C. The second man is ED WITWER, Anderson's second in command late thirties, big like Anderson, good face, strong in th shoulders, short brown hair. The two men are deeply comfortable together.  They can sp or not.  It doesn't matter -- they still communicate.  Tw good cops, good together. They walk side-by-side around the house, dematerializing holographic decoy cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought we might a had a runner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson seems tired, takes a moment to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a runner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little chase -- that'd been good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty cops on the scene takes the chase out of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) But only eight of us were real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer dematerializes the last decoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ever get a runner, I'd be too old to give chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd chase.  You'd love it,.  Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get to the front of the house and watch the Precrime vehicle holding Johnny zoom SOUNDLESSLY away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it more Johnny boy doesn't get to murder his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) It's a beautiful world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children play on their trikes.  The wives talk among themselves.  The birds sing, the dogs bark. The little girl bounces her red ball again.  She stops a. minute, when two pieces of newspaper blow past her, unexpectantly littering the orderly suburban landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decorated in a 1950's style.  Anderson lies in bed beside his wife, LISA, a pretty, green-eyed brunette.  It is ear morning, they are both awake.  Her hand caresses his ches Maybe they will make love. Lisa's hand stops suddenly on the center of Anderson's ch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Paul.  Your heart's hammering. (playfully) I excite you that much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to her, and the grim set of his jaw makes her sm vanish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to love being a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still a cop.  I'm a factory worker.  We don't catch murderers. We process them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa takes a long breath.  She's been down this road befo She speaks reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the best homicide cop in the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANDERSON snorts disdainfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great -- except there's no such thing as homicide.  What I do best doesn't exist anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUL. (beat) You're the Director of a perfect system.  A Cop with a perfect record

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Precogs have a perfect record. They identify the accused -- I just put on my monkey suit and go round them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa hugs him, kisses the back of his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then I prosecute them.  And they go to jail.  And lives are saved. Thousands of lives. (beat) And that's a cop's dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson is silent for a time.  He sighs, then smiles, an turns to his wife, takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You're a cop's dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson steps out of the shower, and begins to towel him dry- He glances out a casement window.  He tilts his head curious, then wipes at the steam on the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa stands in the backyard in her nightgown, talking on cell phone.  She hangs up, moves quickly back into the ho

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Cocks his head, then goes back to toweling off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checkered linoleum floor.  Appliances out of the 1950's. Except there are little differences.  When Lisa puts a sk of eggs on the stove, the heating element is not an elect coil, or gas but a shimmering field of light. Lisa is dressed in a blue jersey skirt and a brief jacket Anderson wears a gray suit, thin blue tie, white shirt, wingtipped shoes.  He doesn't look up from the newspaper he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa keeps her back to him as she flips the eggs.  She to her long brown hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one.  I called about my hair. Getting it done this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson looks like he's about to say something else, whe suddenly someone RAPS on the back screen door.  Anderson Lisa both turn and smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in, neighbor.  Want some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE DOOR
dialogues.text: FRANK D'IGNAZIO, 65, white-haired, robust, hesitates befo coming in.  A thin METALLIC ARM with a red laser light ar quickly down from above the doorway, shines into each of EYES, scanning the irises.  The arm lifts out of view, th screen door UNLATCHES. Frank enters the kitchen, carrying a basket of tomatoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brought these for your supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Frank.  That's so sweet.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet, nothing.  I gotta get rid of these things.  One plant, and I'm invaded by tomatoes.  When I was a kid ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson laughs, claps his friend and neighbor on the bac teases him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before all this genetically engineered crap ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank gives him an ornery look, then a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah well, it's true.  It used to be a challenge to grow things.  An art. Now you put one plant in the ground -- then jump the hell out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson gestures for Frank to sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, thanks.  Can't stay.  You guys are rushing off to work anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa sets the eggs down in front of Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Ellie come for supper then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll barbecue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank nods and pushes on the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You betcha.  We'll bring some more tomatoes -- a new batch will have grown by then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh, Frank exits, Anderson goes back to his pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson waves to Lisa.  Her big Studebaker drives off do the tree-lined street and away. Anderson approaches his Chevy.  He doesn't take out a key unlock it.  There is no lock.  He slides in behind the wh Doesn't take out a key for the ignition -- there is no ignition. A thin METALLIC ARM arches down from the sun visor, scans Anderson's EYES, identifying him.  A seat harness wraps a him, and the car STARTS. Anderson picks up a folder marked "Precrime" and begins t read through the papers.  The Chevy backs out of the driv and takes him to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vast spread of corporate and government buildings -- th spillover from Washington D.C. across the Potomac River i Virginia. Beyond the white of Washington is "The Sprawl" -- the mas unzoned city that has spread uncontrolled on the outskirt of the Capitol.  It is impenetrable and uninviting, espec to those comfortable in the utopian suburbs. Anderson's Chevy moves in a sea of fifties-type cars. Occasionally, an ultramodern vehicle zips past them.  In sky above is another sea -- of advertising dirigibles, holographic billboards, hovercrafts, skim-jet transports. On one of the holographic billboards giant words begin to flash: "I LIKE MIKE!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then a picture of the smiling President appears.  Then th words: "RE-ELECT PRESIDENT MIKE BILLINGS FOR ANOTHER FOUR

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE ANDERSON'S CHEVY
dialogues.text: Through his windshield, Anderson glances at a holographic road sign. THE ROAD SIGN reads: "FBI Headquarters 1 mile.  CIA Headquarters 1.5 miles.  PRECRIME Headquarters 2 miles." Anderson goes back to his papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson sits in a too large office in a too large chair. He abruptly rises and begins to pace.  The room is large, but he paces like a lion confined in a cage. He punches an intercom.  A female VOICE responds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Director Anderson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Ennis Page?  Why hasn't he delivered this morning's Precog discs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Witwer opens the door to the office., and casually wal in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find him, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed shakes his head, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullying the staff again, Director Anderson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson turns away and stares out a large window.  Witwe joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that fun for you, yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Johnny Palmer bust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was okay.  We got our man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson takes a long breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do we not get our man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn as Ennis PAGE, 44, a thin, tight little man wit burr cut hair, knocks and enters the room.  He carries a black BRIEFCASE marked: "Zone 218 - Washington/Alexandria, VA." The case is cuffe to his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late, sir.  Precogs put out a heavy national volume this morning -- four for our zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (DISTRACTED) Put the case on my desk, Ennis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page hesitates, doesn't do it.  Anderson moves quickly to Page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was I thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson leans over the BRIEFCASE.  A small panel recedes red laser scanner clicks on, scans Anderson's eyes, BEEPS affirmatively, then clicks off.  The cuff on Page's wrist falls open. Now Page puts the case on Anderson's desk.  Page hesitate Anderson and Witwer know just what he's going to do.  Pag reaches down, unable to resist straightening a pile of pa strewn on Anderson's desk. Anderson and Witwer exchange knowing smiles.  When Page l up they try to cover, but are not quick enough.  He frown tightly, and heads for the door. Anderson calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ennis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer turns to leave, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's a guy who really cares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer grins to himself as he walks out of the office. Anderson takes a deep breath and goes to his desk, and op the briefcase.  Four small bright DISCS sit in rows.  He removes one, places it in a VIDEO MONITOR that lifts into view from the center of his desk.  He sits back, weary, a watches.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO SCREEN
dialogues.text: A young black woman stands in a hallway.  She stares at a door, gun in hand.  She opens the door, enters a bedroom. She glides toward a bed, where a man lies sleeping.  She lifts the gun and fires it into his sleeping form. ANDERSON pops the disc, jots down some notes, pops in a n disc.

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO SCREEN
dialogues.text: A white woman stands at a stove, cooking.  A man comes up behind her slowly, silently, a necktie taut between his h He raises the necktie toward her neck

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON
dialogues.text: He's not watching the screen.  He is out of his chair now looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tour of Precrime is in progress, like the public relati tours run by present-day FBI.  The TOUR GUIDE, a pretty, smartly uniformed woman in her twenties, leads a group of adults and children, all with glowing nametags, through t building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the main headquarters of Precrime.  Smaller Precrime branches are scattered throughout the United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group follows the guide slowly through the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precrime was established in 2030, with the harnessing of the remarkable talents of the Precognitive mutants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points cheerfully to a stubby little man, MR. HARRIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Harris, can you tell me how many Precogs there are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three.  Uh, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly right!  A lot of people assume there are Precogs in every branch office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there are only three Precogs, right here in this building.  And the information they give us, we send out to all the other branches. (beat) And what is that information -what do the Precogs do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eager boy, TIMMY has the answer to that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They protect us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guide tousles his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chipper voice) That's right, Timmy.  Because of the Precogs, you're going to grow up murderfree.  Isn't that something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ever wrong?  The Precogs ever screw up when they predict a murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guide laughs tolerantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never, sir.  It's an infallible system.  The Precogs predict a homicide, and our Precrime police then apprehend that future murderer before the event occurs.  And right next door is the Judicial Center, where we prosecute the future murderers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we see the Precogs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry.  That part of the building is not open to the public. (beat) Now, if you'll just step this way ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waves the group on toward an elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chamber is an elaborate, hypertech hospital, construc for the maintenance of three beings -- the Precogs.  They are triplets -- two of the Precogs are male, one is femal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technicians swarm all over them like worker bees.  The bo of the Precogs are being tended to: exercised, cleansed, groomed. The head of each Precog is encased in a complex, ornate H that seems to be an amalgam of organic tissues and bright metallics.  The helmets pulse slightly, and the surfaces seem to flow and shift, like oil on water. A network of micro-thin cables that are actually strands light, rise Medusa-like from each helmet, then centralize into a single strand, and connect to a massive mainframe computer. The Precogs appear to be in suspended animation, or in co They are absolutely still and limp -- except for their fa Their faces are in constant motion, the lips mouthing sce from murders only they can see.  Life for a Precog is an endless cycle of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: we recognize her fragile and perfect FACE from the openin scene of the movie.  She floats in a glowing nutritive ba Like her brothers, she seems to be eternally young, or eternally old. The technicians lift her from her bath.  She is dried, dr in a robe, then guided into an over-sized, throne like ch Her brothers are guided into their thrones, on either sid of her. Not once are their helmets removed.  What they feed into mainframe is too valuable.  It must be gathered twenty-fo unrelenting hours a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis Page sits in a room just off the Precog Chamber.  H can see them through a large window.  He works a large computer console, the gathering point for the information the Precogs constantly feed the computer. Perhaps every ten seconds, a small DISC is released by th computer, and mechanically gathered, sorted, and placed - Page's watchful eye -- into a black case. ANDERSON is in the room standing quietly behind Page.  As Director, Anderson is authorized to come and go, but from his fussy movements, it's obvious Page sees anyone else i the room as an intruder in his special domain. Anderson turns and looks through the window at the Precog

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would they think about if we unhooked them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page looks up from his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't think, sir.  They just see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not even alive, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson contemplates the scene, nods to Page's words, th turns and walks out of the room, as Page looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The female Precog sits in her chair.  Her eyes are open. She faces the window that looks into Page's main frame ro In the window we see Anderson leaving the room. The female Precog's eyes drift closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trial is in progress.  The defendant is Johnny Palmer. sits, ashen, at a table, his DEFENSE ATTORNEY beside him. There are no jurors in the Juror BOX.  There is a JUDGE, and stern.  There are a few people in the public seats. The Precrime prosecuting attorney is Lisa Anderson.  She wears a black robe, and addresses the Director of Precrim Anderson, who sits in the witness stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Director Anderson, do you swear that the disc you now present to the court is the only and authentic disc of the future murder of Carol Palmer by her husband, John Palmer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a ritual that they both have acted out hundreds of times.  Anderson gives the rote answer as he holds up the DISC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  This is the only and authentic disc of the event seen by the Precognitive mutants and recorded by the Precrime Division.  This is the immutable evidence of the infallible system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The murder of Carol Palmer will occur ... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In one week -- June 16th, 2040 at 10:33 in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa steps back.  The judge reaches out and Anderson hand him the disc.  The judge inserts it into a special video machine on his desk.  Anderson steps down, his ritual par in this trial completed. A huge MONITOR comes to life behind the judge.  He does n turn around to watch -- he has his own monitor. Johnny Palmer watches, eyes wide.  We now see, in detail, what we previously heard the Precogs act out in the begin of the movie.

dialogues.speaker: THE MONITOR
dialogues.text: The Palmer's family room.  Johnny reaches into Carol's se basket for the scissors.  Carol stands defenseless in fro of him.  Their son cowers in a corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny, please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Johnny, please.  Johnny please."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're scaring me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DADDY, DON'T.  DADDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny approaches his wife with deadly menace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considering) I don't like you any more, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imploring) Put the scissors down.  You're scaring me. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut away from the monitor and stay on JOHNNY PALMER'S as he sits at the defense table.  He winces at each terri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny!  Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't grab at me!  Let go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy!  No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny Palmer cries out as the MONITOR goes blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do it.  I'm innocent!  It didn't happen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUDGE hits his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does the defense plead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The defense attorney glances at his watch, then quickly rattles off the words to his part of this judicial ritual

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The defense acknowledges the infallibility of the system.  We are Guilty.  We throw ourselves at the mercy of the court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No! The Precogs are wrong!  No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The court guards are on him in an instant.  They lead him out of the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson pushes down a tight hallway thick with police an enters a disheveled room.  The fifties interior is drab: Formica table, bad curtains, a frayed Lazy Boy positioned front of a TV. Ed Witwer is already on the scene.  He stands a few feet from the BODY of a man, gunshot wound to the head, a hand on the floor nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Anderson) Looks like the old days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson nods to his former partner.  Anderson leans over the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be bad news for an infallible system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer is suddenly bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know it can't be a murder -- the Precogs would've seen it.  Why do you insist on coming to these things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeps the system honest.  And besides, I like to pretend I'm a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson turns to an officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's got the Coroner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another OFFICER steps forward with a large blue case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer places the case beside the corpse, and opens latches.  Inside the case is a large metallic APPARATUS: "Coroner." It comes to auto-life, and begins to unfold itself - It r crab-like, and steps out of its case. Except for his mouth, the doctor doesn't move.  His proje image stands beside the body, his arms folded behind his back.  He is the interface, the way the humans communicat with the crab apparatus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi DOC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Director Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coroner crab begins to walk the body, which is face d on the floor.  It moves slowly, hesitating as it crawls t body's back to insert various razor thin probes and core samplers through the shirt and into the spinal cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This a homicide, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm presently analyzing neurohormones, Assistant Director Witwer.  I have not concluded my examination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crab engulfs the back of the head, probes the wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm detecting carbonization of skull fragments around the entry wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer whispers to Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo.  The guy put the gun to his own head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have not determined that yet, Assistant Director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have good ears for a ghost, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coroner crab steps away from the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please rotate the corpse to the lateral supine position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two officers turn the body face-up.  The crab inches clos to probe the face.  Disconcertingly, it lifts the eyelids and examines the interior of the mouth, so that for a mom the manipulation makes the corpse seem alive. Then the crab moves down the trunk and the legs At last, comes to a standstill.  The holographic Doctor closes his eyes as if in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you imagine if this was a homicide?  Who even knows how to hunt down a killer any more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson gives him a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how, dammit.  You know how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, partner. (beat) But you know what I'm saying.  The state legislatures are pushing to stop funding for training homicide detectives ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless the Precogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This event is a negative homicide. A mortal wound was generated by a .22 calibre bullet self-delivered to the parietal 'portion of the skull on June 10th, 2040, at 11:57 pm,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eastern Standard Time.  This event is a positive suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The holographic doctor begins to shimmer, then disappears back into the coroner crab.  The crab crawls back into it case, folds its probes and legs tight to its metal body, shuts down. Witwer turns to Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to stop coming to these, partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson watches as the med techs lift the body onto a stretcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  You're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson, in black-tie, with Lisa in a shimmering blue go at his side, moves through a huge room filled high level government officials and politicians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little bit of me dies every time I come to one of these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a party, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd never have let them appoint me to Precrime if I'd have known this was going to be part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're exactly what Precrime needed. An amazing homicide cop and a real person in an unreal job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The public loves the Precogs.  But they give people the creeps, too.  You're something they understandp a regular cop running things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson sighs as he looks around the elegantly appointed banquet hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's invite all these irregular assholes over for a barbecue.  Burgers and beer - think they'd come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A barrel-chested man with a great shock of pepper gray ha SENATOR MALCOLM, 58, takes hold of Anderson's elbow from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd come, Mr. Director.  And I'd make all the other assholes come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa reddens, Anderson gives an embarrassed cough.  The Senator laughs and claps him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice job this morning.  Another negative homicide.  The Precogs never let us down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Malcolm smoothly occupies Lisa, while the Senator ea Anderson in the opposite direction

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a dream, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you do, Senator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundreds of Precogs.  Not just predicting murders, but predicting all crimes.  Burglary, arson, assaults ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about jaywalking?  Littering? Now there's a crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Senator smiles through his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want a police state, you know that.  But we have an opportunity here, and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sir, we don't have that opportunity.  There are only three Precogs.  They're a lucky accident of nature.  There are no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) We can make more.  Just give me your support.  Help me increase funding for the Precog Engineering Project.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precogs aren't sheep or pigs.  Seeing into the future is a gift, a nonreproducible event.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was only one Mozart, and there are only three Precogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck Mozart.  The people want to be safe.  They want that more than they want food or love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures at the room full of glittering partygoers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at us -it's 2040 and we've wrapped ourselves up in the 1950's like a big security blanket.  Why? Because we want to feel like they felt.  Safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator, a world filled with hundreds of Precogs is not my idea of a safe place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Senator gives it one last shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure could use your help, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I decline, Senator.  I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icily) Don't think I'll come to your barbecue after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The senator moves off.  Anderson stands stiffly among the sea of black-ties and exquisite fifties dresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson walks through the lab with a tall, pale man, DR, RESFIELD, 60, the head scientist.  It is not a place that warms Anderson's heart. Biotechnicians work at long stainless steel tables dissec and examining protoplasmic tissue masses.  Other technici peer through massive microscopes.  Still others use robot arms to manipulate radioactive organics behind leaded-gla barriers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't get out here much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not my sort of place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Resfield emits a dry little laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The head of Precrime squeamish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it comes to needles and scalpels, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise we won't use any on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you use them on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) On bits of this and that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson looks at him.  The doctor pauses outside a thick door.  An IdentiScan device quickly reads their eyes, and the door opens with an electronic hiss. Anderson looks around the lab.  Technicians lower mesh cylinders into some sort of chemical VAT.  Another techni turns a dial, and an electric charge courses through the roiling liquid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in an interesting phase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in the cylinders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neurotissue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From ...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fusion of sources.  From the Precogs' deceased mother.  From the Precogs themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fusion of ... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In lay terms, we mated sperm from the brothers with ova from the mother and sister to create new growth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CYLINDERS shudder as the voltage is increased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then we add mutating variables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson stares into the roiling vat.  Dr. Resfield waits for more questions.  But it is clear from Anderson's expression he has already learned enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson sits in his office reviewing Precog discs for premurders in the local Washington area. We stay on him a watches the monitor.  He pops the disc, jots down some no slides in the next disc. Anderson's mouth slowly opens.  He leans close to the mon his face ashen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is on his hands and knees, working his vegetable ga He whistles softly under his breath as he trowels the ric soil. He sits up as he hears someone open the garden gate.  He lifts his straw hat in greeting, gives a smile.  It's ANDERSON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing, playing hooky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson tries to smile.  But it won't come.  He looks ar the abundant garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's great out here, Frank.. You got the touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank straightens with a grimace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the arthritis, is what I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson reflexively looks up at a high WHINING sound fro over head.  Frank follows his gaze.  A Precrime HOVERCRAF glides into position overhead. Frank stares, then lowers his eyes to the ground.  He tak a long sad breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah shit, neighbor. (beat) Goddamn Precogs don't miss a beat, do they? (beat) Can we do this inside?  Ellie's not home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson's voice is full of pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Frank.  Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank wanders the kitchen, trying to focus on his situati Anderson has trouble meeting his friend's eyes. Through a window we can see black suited police officers with mirrored helmets swarming outside Frank's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) I thought I'd buried it all. Thirty-five years -- all those minutes and days to bury it. (beat) But suddenly you see the man who murdered your daughter walking the streets -- my God it throws you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stops pacing.  He stares at a kitchen drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd served his time, Frank.  I know it's not fair.  It's way beyond not fair ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank looks.  At Anderson bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells) God damn the Precogs.  You know? Why couldn't they have been around to save my girl? (softly) Now they're catching me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank reaches into the drawer and pulls out a small handg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really shoot the bastard, huh? When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next Wednesday, at noon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson's cop eyes are all over the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not in you, Frank, to kill anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell it to the Precogs.  It's set in stone now, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank puts the gun on the kitchen counter.  Anderson rela

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost inaudible) I don't want to be a part of this world anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank gives Anderson a look -- no, friend, you don't know Then Frank looks hard at the gun on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) So.  Tell me, Paul.  Do the Precogs see everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they won't have seen this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank suddenly snatches up the gun and presses it to his head.  On Anderson's anguished FACE, at the SOUND of the going off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson stands with his old partner, Witwer, on Frank's front porch.  Behind them, through an open door, we see L comforting Ellie D'Ignazio in the living room. Anderson is deeply shaken.  Witwer tries to talk him thro it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (GENTLY) We had to bring him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a future murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) You blame him?  The guy killed his daughter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer lets the implication of his words sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I know.  I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson turns and watches as they wheel Frank's draped b into the back of an ambulance.  Anderson's bitterness eru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate the Precogs, Ed. I believe in them absolutely and I hate them absolutely.  Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer listens to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that goddamn lab trying to grow more of them.  Put a Precog in every home, you know?  So we can have more Franks - people shooting themselves -- over who knows what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer kneads Anderson's shoulder, talks to him in soothi tones like you'd calm an agitated horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precrime did the job it was supposed to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men can hear Ellie sobbing inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it.  And you believe in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not easy.  It beats us down. Ellie in there -- no doubt she hates you right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson turns to Witwer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I got into this business -- to be hated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson almost manages a small smile.  Witwer puts his a around him.  Walks him away from the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hated us when we were regular cops.  Now we're Precrime, and they still hate US.  It's one of the little perks of law enforcement nobody knows about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their quiet laughter is tinged with sadness.  Anderson lo into his partner's good, open face.  Then they both look away, their understanding of each other complete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson stares out the window at Frank's house, illumina by the moon.  It's a mournful sight. Lisa rises on an elbow and watches him from the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis Page, in the mainframe room just off the Precog Cha picks up a black BRIEFCASE marked: "Zone 218 Washington / Alexandria, VA." He approaches the door, and his eyes are scanned.  The door opens with a HISS. We follow Page as he walks through doors and corridors un he reaches a long hallway leading to the Director's offic Anderson's secretary, Angela, looks up on Page's approach She nods.  He nods. He walks around her desk.  His eyes are scanned, and the door to Anderson's office opens. ANDERSON looks up, wearily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson inserts a disc into the video monitor, almost absently.  As we have seen him do before, he swivels his chair away from the monitor, and stares at Washington D.C across the Potomac.  Hovercrafts and transports skim thro the sky above the Washington Monument. The camera stays on Anderson's back as the sound from the Precog disc begins.  He hears his own voice speaking in strained, agitated tones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not do this, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson slowly swivels around and stares with disbelief horror at the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: THE MONITOR
dialogues.text: shows Anderson and Witwer in a room, a few feet apart poi guns directly at each other.  Their eyes intense and pani Who murders whom? Ed's eyes cut to a huge digital clock on the wall as the seconds tumble away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ed ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer lowers his gun.  He stands unresisting before Anderson. Witwer sees his own death in Anderson's wild eyes, has al seen it. Anderson FIRES his weapon, puts a bullet straight into Witwer's heart, throwing him back against a wall.  Witwer slumps, dying, beneath the huge digital clock, which read 5:20 AM.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Anderson stares as the monitor fades to a blank.  His han goes to his mouth.  His body begins to shake.  He hugs himself, but he can't stop the shaking. The DISC pops out of the side of the monitor.  It is a sm SOUND, but it has Anderson up and out of his chair as if were a gunshot, He reaches for the disc but cannot touch His legs suddenly weaken, and he drops to one knee beside his desk, like a man in need of prayer. There is a single thought that screams through his brain. It is an almost visible thing, filling the room, blackly. Anderson whispers the sickening words that shape his fate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kill you. (beat) Oh god, I kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Anderson pulls himself up, and tries to reach again fo the disc ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an image just like the scene in the beginning of the m the three FACES of the Precogs hover in the misty darknes Their closed eyes open in SUDDEN UNISON.  They speak as o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murderer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a long moment, the eyes close again, and the Precog fade into the mists ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson looks up sharply at the SOUND of a knock on his door.  Every normal sound seems grotesquely AMPLIFIED, th traffic outside, his own breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His senses are on overload. The door begins to open.  A stockinged leg is the first t Anderson sees.  His secretary, ANGELA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates before fully entering the room, Anderson gr at the incriminating disc.  He sees his EYES reflected in its alloy surface.  He pushes the disc deep into his pant pocket. Somehow he finds his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.  Angela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, uncertain.  Then she places a small sta of papers on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need you to sign these.  And your eleven o'clock starts in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ... eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Budget coordination with the FBI. (beat) You okay, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson runs his hand through his hair, can't think fast enough.  He sees her glance at the black Precog disc case He shuts it, awkwardly, and it auto-locks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have Page take this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela steps back, disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sir, the procedure

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make procedure.  Call him. (long beat) I'm not okay, Angela ... you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My head and stomach.  I'm going down to the clinic.  Or m just home. Angela looks relieved at the explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves past her.  His FINGERS fidget against the hidden disc in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll speak to Witwer, put him in charge for the rest of the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hesitates at the door, turns to look at his office, an at his view of Washington.  Then he is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson looks in the door Of Witwer's empty office.  He takes a step inside. Witwer's booming voice sounds from behind him, startling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breaking and entering.  That'll get you five to ten, hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer immediately scans his old partner's ashen face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson can hardly bear to meet his friend's eyes.  He REACHES into his pocket, as if to lift the disc into the light.  If he could just do that, show it to Witwer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson's hand comes out of his pocket, EMPTY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take over for me today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer makes a show of backing away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give it to me.  You probably have that Trans-10 virus going around. A stomach thing.  I hate stomach things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson Almost smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer looks at him.  Anderson almost reaches out for him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run the place, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Sure.  Right into the ground. (beat) Go on home before I call Infectious Control and have them spray you down with something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson moves unsteadily down the hallway.  Witwer calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to do the discs, or hold them for you to review when you get back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't let them back up.  Do 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call you later.  Take it easy, all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer lifts his hand in farewell, Anderson fixes on that last image -- Witwer waving goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson, sweating now, leans against a thick cement pill and pulls out a cell phone.  He hits a button.

dialogues.speaker: BETWEEN ANDERSON / LISA AT THE JUDICIAL CENTER
dialogues.text: Lisa sits in a meeting.  Her phone CHIRPS softly.  She gl at the display, then rises to take it.  She goes to a cor of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa presses her phone close to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hardly hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm underground.  Weakens the signal so it can't be picked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alarm moves across her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we're on Secure

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, dammit!  I'm going to murder Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Precogs picked it up. On Lisa -- can she have heard right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul.  Paul His crackling voice faintly comes through the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa's phone goes dead.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ANDERSON
dialogues.text: Anderson looks down a long row of parked Precrime ground transports.  They are sleek and menacing, the black shell lumpy with dangerous gadgetry.  In the distance, a POLICE OFFICER, holding an armful of equipment, opens the back o one of them. He looks up at Anderson's approach.  He puts his equipmen down, and salutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson nods, moves close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, uh, Robert Smythe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These the new Python transports?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young officer turns and looks at the transport with p is about to speak, when Anderson touches a palm-sized Nov stun gun to the base of his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Sorry, Officer Smythe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer buckles.  Anderson catches him, rolls him gen into the back of the transport. Then Anderson quickly reaches into the transport, and beg stuffing equipment into a duffel bag: a helmet and black uniform, the weapon-glove, a folded rifle, a holographic scanner, and other equipment whose function we can only g at. Anderson looks up at a sound, echoey FOOTSTEPS.  They approach, then fade away. Anderson places the officer's hands and legs together, th aims a nozzled cylinder at them.  He shoots a spray of bl BindFoam chemical restraint, sticking the man to the floo of the transport in an adhesive glob. Then he leaves the scene, running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson grips the wheel of his Chevy, driving down 1-95. The fact that he can't control his car -- that the steeri wheel has no function, his speed is predetermined, and hi direction is guided by satellite -- is maddening now. From inside the cars that glide along beside him people t and look curiously at the man who is actually gripping hi steering wheel. Anderson slams it with his fist.  Through his windshield Anderson sees a four year old boy in the driver's seat of passing red and black Ford.  His mother sits in the passenger's seat, blithely reading.  The boy mimics Ander gleefully slams his steering wheel too, then laughs. Anderson turns and looks the other way, into the distance at the "Sprawl,' the vast unzoned city attached to Washin D.C. You can see it in his face: a man could lose himself there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson stands on an embankment.  He holds the Precog di in his hand, ready to throw it into the river. He stands like that ... and then slowly lets his hand dro He doesn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa enters the house, in a rush.  Every shade is drawn. Paul Anderson sits in an overstuffed chair, absolutely motionless, like a man who has died suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa doesn't get it.  She continues toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!  Moving heats you up, makes it easier for them to pick you up on their thermals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, scared, stops in her tracks.  She is suddenly suffocating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hundred degrees in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I turned the furnace all the way up. Your hair dryer.  The oven.  If they come, it'll buy me twenty seconds. Maybe thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's coming for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the phone -- what you said.  It's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head in disbelief.  Anderson speaks, choki on the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to kill Ed Witwer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson's right hand hangs over the side of his armchair We see the bright DISC cupped in the palm.  He seems abou to reveal it to her, but doesn't, yet.  He keeps staring her intently.  Something is holding him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're upset.  You've been unhappy. There's a lot of pressure on you. And then Frank ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One week from today.  Tuesday, June 25, at five-twenty in the morning. I shoot him, Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) You need to take time off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson laughs harshly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to worry about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) I want to hold you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you love me, stand there.  And don't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears well in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the disc, Lisa.  I shoot him. In the chest.  And he dies.  I've watched a thousand murders.  This time I star in one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's wrong.  You wouldn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Precogs are never wrong.  They emit a single disc.  "The immutable evidence of the infallible system."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is terribly hot, his words -- she begins to sway unsteadily. Anderson focuses on her.  Her face.  Her hair ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll figure this out.  We'll review the system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no review.  There's only the disc.  It Shows My guilt.  There's no defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her long hair.  He stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't run.  Please, let's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SOUND outside.  They both turn.  A deep silence.  The furnace churns out heat.  And Anderson looks at Lisa's ha ... and finally understands. Slowly, and very carefully, Anderson slides the DISC back into his pocket.  He rises from his chair.  For the first time he goes to her, reaches out, and touches her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last week.  It was strange.  I watched from the bathroom window.  You went out in the backyard to make a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An appointment, you said.  For a haircut that afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa's hand jumps to her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't get your hair cut.  You went to the trouble of calling first thing in the morning.  It was that important ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches for him.  He pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it!  Paul, please.  You're panicking.  Everything's going to look wrong.  You're going to distrust everybody and everything now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa implores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't distrust me. (beat) It was Ed I called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson cocks his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed.  why outside?  Why lie about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop being a cop and listen to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A booming, electronically altered VOICE suddenly penetrat the walls of the house from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Director Anderson!  There is no escape!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson, betrayed, glares at his wife.  She's frantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your birthday's tomorrow!  We wanted to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But be's already on the move, running for the upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop to your hands and knees and stay there.  Precrime is entering your house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa screams, as her front door is sonically BLASTED off hinges, and a swarm of Precrime officers in mirrored helm hurtle in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move past her and spread through the rooms and up th stairs like a disease in fast motion.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: Helmeted officers hold their gloved right bands palm out, scanning rooms for thermal presence. An OFFICER 1 steps out of a small room.  He speaks, his v electronically altered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a hair dryer going.  Screwed up my reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not picking up shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rush into rooms, with increased urgency.  We follow OFFICER 1 as he moves counter to the group and down the stairs. He hesitates as he moves through the living room, which i awash in personnel.  Lisa stands against the wall, pale a shaken.  He looks at her for a long beat, then steps over the shattered door and out into the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Everywhere else in the neighborhood it is green and calm. But Anderson's house looks like a wasps's nest someone ha kicked.  Four Precrime hovercrafts are suspended above it engines WHINING.  Black Python transports are all over th street out in front, and more keep coming. And everywhere on foot, there are Precrime police.  OFFIC I approaches a Python ground transport.  Another officer guards it, weapon out, his head turning right to left.  H settles on OFFICER 1's approach and raises his weapon. OFFICER 1 doesn't even break stride.  He walks right up t the guard -- and then right through him.  A holograph dec OFFICER 1 enters the Python.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE PYTHON
dialogues.text: OFFICER 1 removes his helmet -- it's Anderson.  And then comes the moment of truth -- have they cancelled his IdentiScan access to Precrime vehicles yet? A little scanner arm arches down from the visor, and flas a red beam into his eyes.  Anderson presses his lips toge The Python turns on, and a generated voice greets him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Anderson 0256 clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson grips the steering wheel.  But his time, since i is a law enforcement.  Vehicle, the steering actually wor Anderson pulls out. FROM ABOVE, as the Python transport slips away from the c THEN HIGHER, and we see that the direction the Python is headed will take it from the green of the suburbs, throug the white of Washington, and into the dark of The Sprawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Witwer sits alone in an antechamber.  He stares at an oversized oak door, then looks down at the floor. He runs both hands through his hair.  He is tired, his ey weary, lost. A voice comes over the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enter now please, Assistant Director Witwer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer pulls himself together, and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer takes a seat at the end of a long table. Powerful men sit at the other end of the table.  SWANSON, sharp-boned, the FBI Director.  CRONIN, awl-like eyes, th CIA Director.  Senator Malcolm.  Chief Justice POLLARD, w face reveals nothing.  Vice-President ALMER, whose tongue darts across his dry lips unsettlingly.  Unpleasant looki men in an unpleasant mood. Cronin looks up from a printout he's been reading and sta at Witwer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The central question is: Why does Anderson want to kill Witwer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cronin holds up the printout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We checked your finances.  His finances.  Nothing irregular, you don't steal from him, he doesn't steal from you.  You haven't done anything that he might have discovered, and vice versa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swanson holds up another sheath of papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personnel checks reveal no ambitious coups planned by you to topple him. (beat) He's done nothing to you, or you to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer presses his lips together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucking his wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIS MOTHER?  HIS BROTHER?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer gives him a bad look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  There we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you are friends, partners, and soul mates.  Anderson has no motive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't think of one. (beat) Maybe JUSTICE POLLARD The Precogs are mistaken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer looks away.  Jesus, he wants out of this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe that, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible) No.  The Precogs are infallible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator Malcolm is impatient with all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're goddam right.  So, gentlemen -screw the motive.  We got a pre-murderer on the run, and a nasty little PR problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very powerful men level their unpleasant gazes on Wit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here is our solution.  You are now Director Witwer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer shakes his head, starts to protest.  Almer silence him with a raised finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precrime must demonstrate its willingness to go after one of its own.  Total impartiality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cronin talks right over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The public must believe that every future murderer is pursued with equal vigor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore, Precrime will put in charge the man best suited to the job.  And who would pursue a murderer harder ... than his intended victim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went after Anderson yesterday -because it was right, and because you believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almer speaks with a tight irony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your belief will certainly grow stronger with each tick of the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer looks at the men with thinly-veiled hatred.  But h does not deny their words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haw long will it take, Director?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wiltwer takes a long breath, concentrates his mind on the task he can't avoid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows Precrime, of course.  And the streets -- he's rusty, but he'll remember how to work them.  It'll come back to him fast.  He's ... the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer almost smiles.  Justice Pollard's not smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not here to praise Caesar -- we're here to bury him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer looks at Pollard, then lifts a finger and touches right eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't avoid iris identification. Every door he opens, every ATM he uses, or taxi or transport he boards -- he'll get scanned. (quietly) It won't take long to find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyes that look back at Witwer are unblinking.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SPRAWL NIGHT
dialogues.text: The unzoned city is full of 1950's iconography, but it al feels different than it did in the suburbs.  Where the bu were Ike, the city is Joseph McCarthy. The fat Ramblers and Studebakers have a little grime on t The women's dresses are tighter and more urgent, the men' suits have some shine at the elbows.  You look over your shoulder here, move faster, and smile a lot less. And some streets you don't go on at all.  Anderson's Pyth moves down one of them.  He stops under a blackened suspe bridge, gets out.  He's still in uniform.  He holds a duf bag. He starts to walk away from the Python, then hesitates. He's left the door open.  He shakes his head at his sloppiness.  Goes back and shuts the door.  Walks away ag

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR
dialogues.text: He's left a small DEVICE on the passenger's seat.  Digita numbers shoot by in reverse.  Something CLICKS.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE CAR
dialogues.text: Anderson continues walking away.  He doesn't look back as the Python is engulfed in a miniature sun of heat and fla It's not a gasoline powered vehicle -- so it doesn't expl It just ceases to exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a smeared window Anderson sees racks of suits and dresses hanging in clear plastic bags.  He gets to work o the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa lies in her bed, alone in the dark.  She listens to almost inaudible sound, a high WHINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Precrime HOVERCRAFT floats high above her house, a dark moon in the low clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A worker stands in the back of the store puzzling over th clean clothes piled on the floor.  It almost looks like a nest, like someone slept there

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUBWAY LATER
dialogues.text: Anderson, in a blue suit and fedora, carrying his duffel bag, stands on a subway platform.  He takes out a cell ph dials a number.  He looks up at the SOUND of a train. The approaching MagLev train has a lit sign on its front car: "33rd Street Express."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Search and Command room.  Witwer moves up and down the ai past technicians who man computers and holographic tracki displays. A Precrime TECHNICIAN 1 suddenly sits upright.  Witwer pi him out of the crowd and zeroes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer grabs a phone, punches a button

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The technicians scramble to pinpoint Anderson on a Glowing holographic MAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson, holding his phone, is IdentiScanned along with everyone else as he steps onto the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another TECHNICIAN 2 calls out to Witwer.  Witwer covers phone mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been Scanned.  He's on the 33rd Street Subway!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TECHNICIAN 1 Calls from the other side of the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His cell phone tracks for The Sprawl. We got him on the Subway, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson sits on a seat in the rear of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why am I going to kill you,Ed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no motive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife calling you before breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were planning a surprise party. It was going to be today. (beat, ironic) Happy birthday, partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This party's no fun, Ed. It's a hell of a surprise, though. (beat) I'm having trouble trusting people, Ed, I gotta tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Precrime, they upload a MAP DISPLAY of the Express tra route.  We see a blue light moving -- the train.  And two separate red dots along its route. An OFFICER points at the dots, and speaks to Witwer in a voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train makes two stops, here and here: 20th, then 33rd Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer covers the Mouthpiece

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the officer) Split the units, go to both

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll never make 20th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer waves him away -- do your job.  Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You there, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here.  You gotta come in, Paul .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a Cop, Ed. I need a motive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.  We'll figure this thing out together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precrime transports zoom through the city

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
