dialogues.text: Anderson looks out the window into the tunnel dark.  He t to Witwer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll get ugly if you keep running. And your eyes, Paul -- every move you make a Scanner will pinpoint you for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw a news flash.  You're the new Director.  Is that the point of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't think so.  But it has to be something, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer looks at the DISPLAY MAP.  We see the blue train nearing its first stop, 20th street.  We see two waves of lighted green dots -- Precrime units heading for 20th and 33rd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul.  Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson sees an overhead light come on in the train: "Ne Stop 20th Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I come in, it puts me close to you.  If I get close ... I may kill you.  I can't risk that. (beat) Anyway, they'd force you to lock me up.  And that'd be it -- I'd never get my chance to solve this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer needs to keep him talking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kinds liking this, in a way, aren't you?  The action ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you get to be a real cop again. We get to flex our muscles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precrime vehicles pull up.  Hovercrafts appear in the sky above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson's train is just finishing off-loading passengers The doors close and the train begins to pull out as the f helmeted Precrime officers flood the platform. One of them points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson is visible through the window, talking on his ce phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer stares at the map.  The train has stopped at 20th street.  But Anderson's still talking.  He isn't getting -- he's going on to 33rd Street, the last stop. Technician 2 presses his earphone close, listens, then ca over to Witwer.  Witwer covers his mouthpiece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have visual verification -- he's still on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer gives him a thumb's up.  We STAY ON Witwer as he listens to Anderson, and watches his train move toward 33 on the MAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to tell you something, partner. You listening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer nods.  Now the MAP shows all the Precrime units swarming toward the 33rd Street subway station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta do this.  I have to figure this thing out. (beat) But listen to me now.  If it was you running, I'd come after you, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer stares at the MAP, at all the units he's sent afte his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a cop.  And I'm a future murderer. (beat) Do your job, Ed. Come after me hard. Because, Jesus Christ, I wouldn't sleep or eat until I had tracked you down and put a gun to your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precrime officers pour down the stairs toward the train platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer watches on the MAP at all the little symbols mergi together, like a gameboard -- but this game ends in a rea confrontation between one man and an army of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't shoot a cop would you, Paul? (beat) Paul?  Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks urgently to the phone technician

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer presses his ear to the phone.  He can hear the sub make its STOP.  Then he hears a chorus of mechanized VOIC -the voices of the Precrime police, the SCREAMS of panick passengers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police.  Everyone down on your hands and knees! (then) Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Precrime officers aim the index barrels of their gloveweapons at ANDERSON, who sits blithely on a seat, ho his cell phone to his ear. Anderson begins to shimmer, then dematerialize ghost-like into nothingness.  He was a holographic decoy. What is actually there on the train seat is Anderson's ce phone.  Rigged to its mouthpiece is a tiny digital voice recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson trots up the stairs and safely out onto the stre of The Sprawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every city has its underbelly.  If you lifted the fat dar underbelly of The Sprawl this is where you'd end up. The streets here feel like alleys, clotted and tight.  Th are streetlights, bright ones -- but the light dies at it source, never makes it through the sour air down to the ground. The retro fifties look comes apart here.  The people that you see -- and you only catch quick glimpses of them, the move like rats -- wear black mostly, tight fitting tech-fibers. ANDERSON'S caught one of the rats, a thin bald guy in bla Anderson has him pinned up against a wall.  They're havin some kind of exchange -- which consists of the guy answer none of Anderson's questions, and Anderson pressing him h against the wall. Finally, the guy does something odd.  He lifts a finger a pulls down Anderson's right lower eyelid.  Anderson lets him.  Then the guy does the same on the left.  Has a long look.  And then nods.  Anderson releases him, and they go off together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An oppressive brick thing on a side street.  The facade i crumbling.  Nothing good happens in a building like this. The guy leads Anderson to the building, then scurries off into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stained overstuffed chair in the corner, a dreary littl kitchen with crusted dishes in the sink. But jarringly, in the center of all this, is a make-shift hypertech medical setup: a gleaming operating table, an a of lasers, scalpels and surgical equipment, an anesthesia console. Anderson sits in a chair facing DOC.  DOC is a big man wi delicate fingers.  He sneezes, then blows his nose hard i a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson looks at him uneasily.  It's not just DOC -- it' the whole setup, the needles and scalpels, the medical th which Anderson truly does not care for.  Doc sneezes agai then looks up at his patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  I could cut open your chest, sew a dead cat in there, and you'd never get an infection.  Not with the spectrum antibios I'll be shooting into you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not here for cat surgery, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc chuckles.  Then he waits, expectantly. Anderson hands him a tiny opalescent card.  A preset cash card.  DOC slides it into small console, watches the numb flash up.  He frowns, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all I could safely move

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits.  Doc's not thrilled, but finally, he nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to got down to business.  Doc walks over to a large medical cabinet and opens the door.  It's full of EYES, a parts of eyes -- 611 !  A cryo-jars. Anderson tightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand what I told you then. I can't just give you new irises. The Scanners will read the scar tissue.  Alarms will go off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a cop, I know

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta take your eyes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson knows this, too, wishes Doc would shut up ANDERS Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And put in new ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I get it, DOC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson rises up out of his chair and goes over to the operating table.  He lies down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me quick before I run out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson lies there, blinking up at the ceiling.  He list to Doc preparing instrument trays.  It's a bad sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suspension bridge where we saw Anderson vaporize the Python transport.  Witwer stands watching as a Precrime techno-unit sifts through the white ashes. Witwer lifts his face to the acrid breeze coursing off th Potomac.  It's a pose a track dog might hold, nose up, te the air for a scent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't see anything at first, because Anderson can't se anything either.  He's in a deep post-surgical haze.  DOC voice comes to him.  It's warped and ugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take the bandages off for twenty four hours.  You'll go blind if you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson makes an affirmative grunt. Now we see his surroundings, even though Anderson still can't.  He lies a grungy bed, his head and eyes swathed in white dressing Doc stands over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in a room.  I had you moved here, a couple miles from my place. If they find you, they don't find me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson grunts weakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy will come in, feed you once. (beat) I juiced up the nano-reconstruction around your new eyes, 'cause I know you're in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Fuzzily)) Nano-re ...construction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Organic microrobots that reconstruct nerves and blood vessels.  It'll feel like fleas chewing on your eyeballs.  Don't scratch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson is already reaching his hands for his bandages. Doc forces them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving you a bonus, might come in handy.  Feel this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc takes an air-syringe out of his pocket and touches it Anderson's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a temporary paralytic enzyme. Someone spots you, you duck into an alley, shoot this under your chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc presses the tip into the soft underpart of Anderson's chin.  Anderson jumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The enzyme turns your facial muscles to mush.  You won't look like the same man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tighten up again in about thirty minutes.  Hurts like nothing you ever felt.  It's vicious, but effective.  I'll put it in your bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Doc takes a small clock out of his pocket and pl it on a dresser beside Anderson's bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm setting up a timer.  When it buzzes tomorrow, take off your bandages, and get the hell out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson, groggy, starts to say something else, but then hears a door open and close, and Doc is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Precrime presence mounts on the streets.  A couple of units move past the boarding house, but they don't stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson sits in a chair, his dressings like a blindfold. He looks like a hostage.  He is sweating.  Keeps reaching for his dressings to scratch, then forces himself not to. He speaks to someone we don't yet see.  The guy DOC said would come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hungry, but sick to my stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I should eat.   (Beat)  You gonna help feed me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the camera moves and we see who it is that has been s to help Anderson.  It's the rat guy, the thin bald man Anderson had roughed up the day before.  The guy has a bo of hot soup in his hands.  He stares contemptuously at Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how do we do this, pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rat guy doesn't say a word.  He simply tips the hot s and it splatters down into Anderson's lap.  Anderson crie out in pain and surprise.  The guy walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty hours gone by.  Four more to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precrime cops are shaking down any of the rats they can c looking for leads, looking for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TIMER shows one hour to go.  Anderson sits in a chair squirming miserably.  His dressings are wet with sweat, a frayed and dirty at the edges where he has tugged and plu at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is this close to ripping the dressings off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Precrime transport stops.  Two officers get out.  One o them sets up a large thermal scanner on the sidewalk, and does a read on the boarding house.  The other does a read a pawn shop and bar next door.. The OFFICER 1 doing Anderson's boarding house, calls to t other officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got 27 warm bodies in this place. What should it take, three or four Spiders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do four.  Speed things up, so we can go eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Officer 1 opens the back of the transport, and takes a box.  He removes four round BALLS.  They are silver, as big as billiard balls. He goes up to the boarding house, gets IdentiScanned, and the front door opens.  He rolls the balls down a dark hal Then he goes back out to the transport, and leans against it, bored.  He holds up an electronic clipboard and waits for the data to come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BALLS roll about eight feet, then suddenly come to autolife as they spin.  They open like flowers -- flowers with legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fist-sized Spider takes shape.  On its head is an Ident lens mounted on a thin metallic antenna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLD WOMAN sits at a card table eating a bowl of someth unidentifiable.  She looks up with annoyance as she sees spider scuttling across the floor toward her.  It makes a CLICKING sound on the floor as it comes.  She's poor, liv in The Sprawl -- she knows the drill.  She continues to e as the SPIDER crawls up the leg of the card table.  She b watches as it moves past her bowl and toward her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to have a little company

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles toothlessly at her joke The Spider hops onto h am and inches up, then moves across her shoulder.  It gri her cheek lightly, as the IdentiScan antenna reads her ey Then it leaps off her and onto the floor and CLICKS away across the linoleum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Precrime officer lifts his clipboard and checks a col with his laser pen, and waits for the next one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson sits in his chair.  He cocks his head, listening His body tenses.  Something feels wrong. The TIMER shows ten minutes to go.  Blindfolded for a day and a night, Anderson has no idea how much time he has le Three seconds, four hours? A flattened SPIDER squeezes under his door.  Anderson ten as it CLICKS across the floor toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows that sound. Anderson stumbles up and out of his chair.  He starts to grab at his dressings, remembers Doc's warning, and stops himself.  The SPIDER waits for him to settle, then CLICKS toward him again. Anderson moves around the room, avoiding the Spider.  He dripping with sweat, starting to breathe hard.  The Spide comes faster.  Anderson crashes into a table, brings it d Falls across the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Officer 1 squints at his clipboard.  One of the Spide is taking too long.  He adjusts his thermal scanner, and sees the heat outline of a man bouncing around a room. The other Officer 2 finishes reading the pawn shop and th barroom, then wanders over to Officer 1. They both watch screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stinking drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Or a guy who doesn't want to get read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson forces himself to sit still, because he knows th consequences.  The Spider advances, starts up his leg. The TIMER has not buzzed.  Anderson can't touch his dress The Spider moves across his shoulder and onto his face. WHIRS and HUMS trying to adjust its antenna against the dressings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officers eye the thermal scanner, as they reach for t mirrored helmets, getting ready to go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Spider crawls all over Anderson's head, trying to get past the dressings for a read. Anderson has no choice.  None.  He starts to lift at his dressing.  The Spider senses his cooperation, freezes in place. Anderson wants to scream.  He unwraps his head, tugs the pads away from his eyes.  He rips them off.  The Spider s on his shoulder, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson's eyes are tightly closed.  He opens them

dialogues.speaker: BLINDING LIGHT
dialogues.text: Light brighter than a magnesium burn, brighter than a nuc flashpoint.  Light to buckle the knees and push the brain beyond endurance. And though all this the faraway sound of a BUZZER going o The TIMER has finally sounded.  Anderson's open eyes are streaming with tears, but he has survived the moment.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: It comes into slow focus The Spider, all business, reads eyes.  Then, as if nothing unusual has occurred, it jumps off his shoulder, and crosses the floor.  It flattens, sc under the door, and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officers see that the Spider has gotten its read.  Th pull off their helmets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start putting their equipment back into the transpor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson stares at himself in a dusty mirror.  His new ey are tender and bloodshot.  And they are not blue, like th ones he was born with, but a deep brown.  Anderson is exa the same, and utterly different. He grabs his duffel bag, and gets the hell out of there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa, looking drawn and scared, sits in Witwer's office. Witwer isn't looking too well, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They told me to move into Paul's office.  I said fuck you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I don't want to do any of this, Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Everybody's got their reasons for wanting you in charge.  So do I -- you won't bring him in dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  But if he shoots a cop ... (beat) Which is what he does four days from now, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer's eyes imp involuntarily to a CLOCK on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd never hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that.  But the other thing I know is -- the Precogs are never wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words are leading them no place good.  They stop talk and just sit there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson stands on a street corner waiting in line with several people waiting for the N0.6 Turbo Tram. The double decker Tram comes.  People get off, then the l starts to move forward as people get on. Anderson fidgets.  He's last in line.  Each person gets IdentiScanned as he boards.  Anderson's putting his new e to the test.  If the scan goes wrong, he's positioned him to run. The woman ahead of him, gets scanned, pays her fare. Anderson's turn.  Anderson goes up the steps, and a red b reads his eyes. The Tram DRIVER glances at a monitor beside his steering wheel, then nods at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome aboard, Mr. Symington.  Plenty of seats in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson nods, moves casually to the back.  But his jaw muscles are flexing hard, working off the tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator Malcolm releases a self satisfied little belch as finishes off a late night whiskey in his panelled den.  H wanders about admiring himself in the many political phot adorning the cherry wood walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's feeling cozy and safe, the way rich people can affor to.  No IdentiScan Spiders would ever be sent under his d No intrusions of any sort, nothing that a coiffed secreta or a loyal wife wouldn't announce before hand. Which is why he doesn't immediately understand the small SOUND at ear level, coming from just behind him.  It's a metallic CLICK-CLICK.  He turns amiably.  His eyes instan widen, and his knees buckle when he sees he's looking int the barrel of ANDERSON'S cocked gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to upgrade your alarm system, Senator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senator Malcolm tries to regain his composure.  His fear embarrasses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your work-up of Witwer.  The Security Panel would've done one. (beat) Why do I kill Witwer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Senator finds his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no motive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's, always a motive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson presses the gun to the Senator's forehead.  He s the barrel tip back and forth across the Senator's sweaty skin.  It makes a greasy red mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could've come to anyone on the panel.  But I picked you. (beat) Of all the shits on that panel, I like you least of all.  So if this gun goes off, I'll feel bad, but not, you know, devastated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can almost see a thought dawning on Senator Malcolm. And then, shockingly he spits in Anderson's face, and tur and walks to the other side of the den.  His tone is mock

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck was I worried about? You can't kill me.  The Precogs would've seen it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson realizes this, too, lowers his gun.  The Senator even laughing now.  For a moment Anderson does nothing, t he moves toward the Senator again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Senator stands his ground smugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer's clean.  You're clean. There's nothing.  No motive.  Kind of like something Kafka would've cooked up. (beat) You like that, cockroach?  You're fucked and you'll never know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Senator is laughing hard now.  Anderson lets him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you something about the Precogs, Senator.  They're great on murder. But it's the little things they fail to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson hits the Senator so hard it bounces him across t floor and into the cherry wood panelling.  Several of his beloved photos crash down onto him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little things like that, for instance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson steps over him, and walks out of the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Search and Command room.  Witwer stands there amidst all the technology speaking to a group of Precrime officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't shown up on one goddamn IdentiScan in three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one says anything, and then LIEUTENANT GLASER, 30, spe up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's found a room -- he's going to sit it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, except for holding a gun to senator Malcolm's goddman head in his own goddman house last night, Anderson's sitting it out! (beat) Why hasn't he been scanned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officers look at their shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is he invisible?  He's moving around but he isn't being seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Glaser tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hes beating the scanners

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one beats the scanners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer reaches up, wearily, rubbing his face and eyes wit his hands.  The fingers dragging across his eyes stop.  T his hands drop away, and he looks at his men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's done his eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the scarring always

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went the whole way.  The crazy bastard had his eyes removed.  New ones sewn in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That takes weeks to heal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're prepared to go blind, a street surgeon'll juice up the repair cycle.  They don't give a fuck about risk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer's eyes flick to a digital CLOCK on the wall.  It's something he can't help doing now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to do what it takes to stay free -- if it blinds him, maims him, or kills him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwers admiring smile makes his men very uncomfortable .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mother places a carton of milk on a table in front of h teenage son.  He pours it into his cereal bowl, then puts the carton down in front of him. There's a flexible Vid-Screen on the side of the carton, about the size of a playing card.  AS the sleepy kid watc the disposable Vid-Screen sparkles to life. Nothing unusual, they always do that.  For advertisements lost kids, or in this case crime bulletins. A good one.  The kid straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: THE VID-SCREEN
dialogues.text: A fully rotating mug shot of PAUL ANDERSON fills the scre followed by vital statistics and details of the precrime he's been charged with. The kid watches for a while, then gets bored, and pulls t Dexi-Pops cereal box over and starts reading the back of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big man in a tee shirt lies on a couch, a bowl of popco perched on his belly.  He stares at a TV monitor that's t size of a twin bed.

dialogues.speaker: TV
dialogues.text: Anderson's face fills the monitor.  The TV image is so bi that Anderson overwhelms the room with his video presence It's like God coming to pay a visit -- even if you want t avoid Him you can't. The big man with the popcorn tries to do just that.  He s through a zillion channels, but Anderson's visage is omnipresent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson's face fills the skies, too.  Witwer and Precrim have pulled out all the stops. Advertising dirigibles float by with Anderson's image on Holographic billboards with Anderson hover in the air.  T are so many Andersons in the sky he seems to be part of t weather, a special type of cloud. People on the streets look up, briefly interested, then g about their business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One person who is paying deep attention to all this is Anderson himself.  He stands on a street corner, wearing dark glasses and a fedora, staring at a public video kios

dialogues.speaker: VIDEO KIOSK
dialogues.text: The mug shot of Anderson disappears and is replaced by a Precrime SPOKESWOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The United States Supreme Court has issued a special injunction allowing the unprecedented public viewing of former Precrime Director Paul Anderson's future murder of Edward Witwer, the current Director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mouth slowly opens.  He steps back against a wall and slides his hand into his pants pocket.  He looks at the Precog DISC in his cupped hand, then quickly puts it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at the kiosk as people on the street begin to g around excitedly. CROWDS OF PEOPLE look into the sky, in store windows, at other video kiosks.  They have the enthralled anticipatio of a mob at a public guillotining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues her declamation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The video you are about to see, generated by the Precognitive mutants, is the immutable evidence of the infallible system. (reassuring smile) Citizens are urged to call 1-800-PRECRIME with any information that may lead us to the whereabouts of Paul Anderson, future murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakes his head in confusion and disbelief.  But he has the Precog disc ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OLD GUY him nudges him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This oughtta be good, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KIOSK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there it is, Anderson and Witwer standing there point guns at each other.  The whole thing just as we saw it be All the way through to the fatal moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ed ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson shoots him.  Witwer slumps, dying.  The video st And then begins to play all over again, right from the st the 1-800-PRECRIME number scrolling along the bottom of i "Call now!  Call now!  Call now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moves quickly through the crowds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis Page sits on a bar stool at the far end of a bar so full of cigarette smoke it doesn't seem capable of suppor life.  But it supports the kind of life Page is intereste in. An emaciated woman with a feral smile slides onto a stool beside Page.  He gives one shake of his head, and she sli away again.  His eyes cut to a group of females.  He wait for the next approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as a HAND reaches over his shoulder and places a Precog d on the bar in front of him.  Page makes a sound and tries jump away, as if the disc is something lethal.  Which it in a way. Anderson presses him back down on his stool.  Sits next t him.  Page stares at him, scared.  Anderson looks straigh ahead as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Ennis Page engages the services of prostitutes because his relationships with them compound his feelings of selfloathing." (beat) Direct quote from your psychological profile -- the kind of shit I had to know as your former boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Page is an obsessive-compulsive Type Nine." Another quote.  Niners are great for the kind of work you do -- keeping all those Precog discs in order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can almost see Page's heart slamming in his chest.  H tries to hide it with tough talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fuck whores and I'm orderly, so what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's out of order, Ennis. Deeply out of order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page looks unhappily at the disc on the bar PAGE You got disc Anderson picks it up, holds it tight in his fist

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not A disc.  The disc.  When I went home sick, I stole it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took it with me, Ennis.  I wasn't sick, I was running with the evidence. (lets that sink in) So how is it that Precrime has one, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (utterly baffled) You can't make copies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson waits.  Lets Page work through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the basis of the system.  The immutable evidence.  Copies are impossible. (beat) You went home.  A little later, I came in with a disc for Mr. Witwer to review.  I wasn't halfway out the door when he cried out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson is barely breathing, he's listening so hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was in shock.  He showed me.  It was you shooting him.  Then all hell broke loose.  He had to send the Precrime units to your house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis -- you gave out the same disc twice.  Less than an hour apart. The one I stole.  And then another one.  Of the same event.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's impossible.  The Precogs can only move forward to new events. Into the future.  They never repeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson looks around.  Patrons are beginning to look ove in his direction, eyes lingering.  He rises. Page seems in a daze.  As an obsessive-compulsive niner, concept of an untidy system is disorienting. Anderson starts to say something to the man, then doesn't On the way out Anderson gets IdentiScanned.  An automatic DIGITAL VOICE calls out after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice night, Mr. Symington

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson leaves the dark of the bar for the deeper dark o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNG GUY with a sparse moustache walks up to a payphon He picks up, the receiver and immediately gets IdentiScan A light goes on, he's about to dial. Anderson appears out of nowhere, shoulders him out of the way.  The young guy drops the receiver and stumbles back onto the sidewalk.  Anderson grabs the hanging receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Hey, you can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches for Anderson, then thinks better of it.  Ander is twice his size and very menacing in dark glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gettin' a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy scurries off.  Anderson dials quickly.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON/LISAS OFFICE
dialogues.text: Lisa, walking down a hallway in the Judicial Center, stop to answer her BEEPING cell phone.  She leans against a wa as lawyers and judges pass by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa grips the phone and turns to the wall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your phone will be bugged.  So we can't meet, we can't do anything. Just listen.  Nowing you're listening is enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa nods, as if he's right there.  He is right there, fo her.  This is all she's got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Precrime stormed the house, I thought you'd called them.  Betrayed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  Witwer sent them.  He saw the disc and had to do his job. (beat) Tell me you forgive me.  Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I forgive you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no time left.  He has to get off the line and sta moving again.  A vast weariness enters his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All these people I need to forgive me. (beat) Do you think Frank forgave me?  All I could do for him was send him gardenias. (long beat) I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa almost cries out when he hangs up.  She flattens her against a wall.  She stays like that for a long moment, pulling the sound of her husband's voice, his words, deep inside of herself. And then she gets a look, as one of those words registers profoundly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to herself) Frank hated gardenias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A public cemetery along the Potomac.  There's not much la left for new graves.  A funeral is taking place.  A lot o mourners in dark 1950's suits and dresses.  The service i nearing its end. Frank D'Ignazio's newly dug grave is nearby.  Lisa stands there, looking at the temporary marker, and the flowers a wreaths piled up against it. Two rows over, they are lowering the casket into the grou High in the sky, a PRECRIME HOVERCRAFT, everpresent in Li life, floats in the low clouds with a barely audible WHIN Lisa rests a floral arrangement against the pile of flowe Her hand drifts near a white GARDENIA WREATH.  There is a small envelope tucked beneath a blossom.  She takes it. Then she rises and begins to walk back to her car. The funeral is over, and the mass of mourners, many weari dark glasses, fan out toward a long line of cars. One of the MOURNERS brushes past Lisa.  She looks up and tips his dark glasses down onto his nose and stares over them at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Anderson.  Isn't it?  She looks into his eyes.  And it's jarring, the blue eyes gone, that they're brown now. But it's him, he's there, and she wants to reach out for him.  Knows she can't. He's already moving on.  He's risked everything for a loo He slips into the black sea of mourners, she goes to her -neither of them ever breaking stride. The Precrime craft hovers, unaware

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa opens the envelope as her car drives her down the Alexandria-Washington ConnectWay. A Precog DISC falls into her hand.  Her mouth opens -- sh never held one before. And there is a NOTE with it It READS: "The Precogs generated duplicate discs.  This is the firs Precrime has the second.  Duplicates.  Why?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson has to eat bad food quickly, and on the run.  He gathers up a wrapped sandwich, a bag of donuts, something drink. He waits in line.  He doesn't like to be in a line, waiti The woman ahead of him argues about change.  He presses h lips together. And then he glances at the mirrored surface of a hidden c DOME attached to the ceiling.  It gives him a fish eye reflected VIEW of what's happening behind him. Precrime police are happening behind him.  He doesn't sto to ponder, as two Python transports zoom up outside the s Anderson vaults the counter, knocking the customer and th clerk to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson plows over a guy filling a trash can.  He hears mechanically altered COMMANDS of a Precrime officer calli from the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Anderson.  Drop to your hands and knees!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson crashes out into an alley, and clambers up a fen SONIC BLASTS shatter the air around him.  Chunks of brick fly off the walls on both sides.  But he is full of adrenaline, and there is no stopping him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A different part of the city.  Anderson hunkers low in th back seat of a tram. He looks up, as the DRIVER swears

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson stands up, looks down the aisle, through the windshield.  Precrime transports are heading straight at tram, going the wrong way on a one way avenue. They've even taken radio control of the P.A. system on th tram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Anderson.  Drop to your hands and knees!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson can't believe it -- how are they suddenly pinpoi him?  The passengers turn in unison like cattle, and star at him, terrified. Anderson grabs his duffel bag and kicks at the back exit doors, smashing them open, and tumbles out onto the stree He rolls, and is up on his feet in a second, reaching int his bag for a glove.  He pulls the weapon onto his right hand, as he whirls around sizing up his predicament. Precrime transports have begun to seal off both ends of t street.  He looks up.  He is surrounded by skyscrapers an buildings -- he is walled in, at the bottom of an urban canyon. People freeze against the sides of buildings, run into doorways where they can.  Passengers in trans and taxis o cars stay there, pressed against their windows watching. Nothing moves, except the Python transports, closing in. The lead officer speaks, with that menacing electronicall altered VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lower your weapon, or we will neutralize your threat potential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Precrime police are out of the transports now, advanc at either end of the city street in phalanxes of men. Anderson eyes the side of the black granite office buildi closest to him.

dialogues.speaker: A HIGH PRESSURE HYDRANT
dialogues.text: The large red hydrant sits a few inches out from the buil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson almost smiles as he begins to walk slowly toward it, his weapon pointing harmlessly at the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson is up on the sidewalk now, two feet out from the building, right beside the high pressure hydrant. He stops, looks up, looks down, looks at the police advan It is a moment for prayer.  Anderson doesn't have a momen He spreads his feet and fires a massive SONIC BLAST down the sidewalk.  The effect on the underground water main i immediate. A GEYSER of water two feet in diameter erupts straight up from the sidewalk, lifting the tumbling Anderson fifteen feet into the air right alongside the building. The stunned police officers try to take aim, but Anderson bouncing at the top of the geyser.  And they can't fire, anyway, because officers workers stare at the excitement from every window in the building. All this in a time span of seconds.  The world spins craz for ANDERSON, but he manages to grip hold of a metal supp beam holding the building's sign, one story up. The police try to see what he's doing, but the torrent of water from the water main break obscures his moves. He pulls himself onto a ledge, steadies himself, slides a it toward a second story window.  The office building gaw lurch backward from the window as Anderson blasts it to sparkling dust and leaps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building covers almost an entire city block.  Anderso dripping wet, runs from one end of it to another, blastin through doors, shoving terrified workers out of the way. He is like a wide receiver running the length of the fiel jumping obstacles, slamming through, over, and around wha he must to get to his goal. And then he reaches his goal -- the windows overlooking t avenue next block over and parallel to the one where Prec ambushed him. He spots a double-decker TurboTram moving slowly in the s of traffic.  It pulls to the curb below to pick up passen Anderson blasts out the window and leaps onto the roof of the bus.  It is a bone-jarring landing.  He loses consciousness for a second, rolls the length of the roof, and slides off it onto the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies there, trying to rouse himself.  Traffic brakes t stop automatically as car and truck sensors read his form the road.  No one wants to touch him.  A single car horn SOUNDS, and then a chorus of them. Anderson rouses, struggles to his feet, and takes off in limping run.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUBWAY STATION LATER
dialogues.text: Anderson, out of breath and in pain, leans against a post the far end of the passenger platform.  There are tracks either side of him, one marked "Uptown" and the other "Downtown. " He feels a blast of air and looks to his right and sees t the Downtown train is coming in.  And on his left, too, t Uptown train rounds the bend and comes into view. Which MagLev train will lead him to safety?  Which one wo they pinpoint?  He runs up to a teenage KID who has his a around his girlfriend.  They step back, startled.  He's g a flat top hair cut, she wears a pleated skirt and saddle shoes. The trains pull in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick one for me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Point to the train I should take. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl lifts a nervous finger and points.  The Uptown. runs to board it, as they run in the opposite direction t the Downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits at the back of the half empty train watching the dark rush by.  A train chosen arbitrarily -- it's impossi they could find him. A station Stop.  He starts to get off, is actually on the platform, then steps back onto the train. The rushing dark again.  When the MagLev eases to a halt the next station he gets off this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks toward the exit stairs with a handful of people. He eases back and lets them go up first.

dialogues.speaker: THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Precrime officers crouch around the bend, silently snatch people out of the way as they come into view.  They wait -but Anderson does not come.  And he does not come. On signal, the Precrime officers rush down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: DOORWAY ABOVE THE STAIRS
dialogues.text: ANDERSON hangs high above the doorway near the ceiling, adhered by one arm there by a blue glob of adhesive BindF

dialogues.speaker: THE OFFICERS
dialogues.text: as they run below him down the stairs.  They go out of si he can hear them rushing along the platform searching for him. The strain of hanging by one arm is killing him.  He reac up.  With a laser knife, and cuts away at his coat sleeve releasing himself from the glob.  He drops to the stairs, and instantly slips up them. He surprises a helmeted OFFICER, just around the bend.  H slams HIM against the wall, yanks off his helmet, and hol the laser knife against his throat. The OFFICER 1s clearly terrified.  He speaks hoarsely thr Anderson's choking grip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't kill me!  Jesus.  Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson looks at the panicked officer.  Anderson closes eyes trying to put it together.  He opens them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the Precogs would've predicted me killing you.  You'd know whether I do or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer looks at him with eyes begging for mercy. Anderson suddenly gets it.  He tightens his grip on the m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shut down the system.  Haven't they?  They've shut down the Precogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're off homicides.  They're redirecting them to help us locate you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is how they knew where he'd be every time. Anderson chops quickly at the base of the man's skull, knocking him out.  And then he runs, because what else ca he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa stands in a long hallway outside a door, labeled: COURTROOM 17.  She holds a briefcase in one hand.  Down t hall, other courtrooms are in use, but not this one.  She enters the dark and vacant Courtroom 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa sits at the judge's bench in the empty courtroom.  T lights are dim. She takes a small, battery-powered tv out of her briefcas She turns it on.

dialogues.speaker: TV
dialogues.text: The murder of Witwer by Anderson is being shown over and over in a continuous loop.  Flashing at the bottom is the hotline number: "1-800-PRECRIME." Then- "Call Now!  Call Now!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Now Lisa takes out the Precog disc Anderson gave to her - first disc. She places it in the specialized monitor on the judge's b The tv and the judge's monitor sit side by side.  The tv plays the version of the murder from the second disc; the judge's monitor plays the version from the first disc. She stares intently, her eyes flicking back and forth fro one version to the other.  They seem absolutely identical When the judge's monitor goes blank, she starts it over a Lisa stares, watching her husband murder his best friend, endlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gas station right out of the fifties.  An attendant in uniform and cap whistles while he wipes down the windshie of a sky blue Rambler. In the background, Anderson walks toward a men's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson looks at himself in the mirror.  He reaches out touches one reflected eye, which is a deep brown.  It is still startling to him, the color of his eyes. Then he reaches into his duffel bag and takes out the air syringe Doc gave to him.  He looks at it nervously.  It i filled with 5 cc's of an opaque green liquid. He touches the tip of it to the soft center under his chi He closes his eyes.  Then he screws up his courage, and h the plunger.  The liquid is pneumatically delivered with searing HISS. Anderson screams out in agony, slams back against the wal of the bathroom.  His hands reach up for his face -- whic looks like it's boiling from within.

dialogues.speaker: ANDERSON'S FACE
dialogues.text: The skin on both cheeks begins to pucker.  The muscle ton around his chin goes soft, and begins to sag like an old man's.  That is the effect -- like he is aging fifty year His forehead wrinkles, the skin under his eyes droop.  He pink is replaced by bloodless gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ATTENDANT knocks nervously on the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the door opens, an unhealthy looking old guy with a fedora hat pulled low comes slowly out of the bathroom. Anderson nods, and walks past the attendant, who watches after him uncertainly as he wanders off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The perky tour guide we met earlier takes another group a the headquarters.  There may be a massive campaign to fin Anderson, but the Precrime public relations machine conti to run without interruption. There are ten people in the group, and the physically transformed Anderson is among them.  They all wear glowin nametags.  Anderson's reads, "Mr. Symington." He keeps hi hands in his pockets, and his head low. We have heard the tour guide's spiel before

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the main headquarters of Precrime.  Smaller Precrime branches are scattered throughout the United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is about to go on when she looks over at Anderson.  H is fidgeting uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ... all right, Mr. Symington?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson moves up close to her, a little too close.  He whispers to her, embarrassed.  She gives him a profession smile, and points in the distance past the elevators. Anderson nods, and heads off.  She calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll wait right here for you, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson runs down a back stairwell to a lower floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson stands outside a door marked: "Housekeeping." Ab the doorway is an IdentiScan device. Anderson reaches into his coat and carefully removes a sm cryo-jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imbedded in the clear gelatinous coolant are two eyeballs -the irises a luminous blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The operations room in Precrime.  The technicians sit at their computers and holographic tracking displays. Witwer paces among them.  His eyes keep flicking to the digital clock on the wall.  Then they cut back to the men and machines that are telling him nothing.  Witwer does n look well at all, When a TECHNICIAN leans close to his computer monitor,Witwer almost leaps across the room to g to him.  He looks over the man's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be a glitch ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson just got IdentiScanned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer grips the back of the technician's chair.  The technician types the data through again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him -- he's been scanned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The technician looks up at Witwer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's had his eyes done.  Right? Sir?  Tries to think it through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible) He had to have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The technician's computer flashes the next piece of information.  When he speaks, it's the last thing Witwer wants to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, sir.  He's in the basement of this building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes turn to Witwer.  The unspoken question hangs in air.  Anderson's come to murder Witwer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throughout the building, every available Precrime Officer begins to receive orders to mobilize toward the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four officers stand guard in the chamber.  They listen to the orders coming in on their earpieces.  Three of the gu rush out of the room, one stays behind. The three Precogs sit in their oversized chairs, the fema in the middle, the males on either side of her.  Their ey are open ... and they are deeply alert. Two technicians tend to the Precogs.  At the back of the chamber, through a large window, we see Ennis Page sittin at the huge mainframe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ring of Precrime officers three men deep stand guard ar Witwer.  Witwer looks like he wants to kill them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Glaser replies forcefully

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing orders from the Security Panel, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he wants to get to me, he'll get to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he won't, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer looks at the confident young officer almost pityin Then his eyes flick to the wall clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armed Precrime officers clog the corridors, conducting defensive searches of one room after another.  All they a coming up with so far are some very startled housekeepers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the chamber are one guard, two technicians, and three Precogs.  And all of them are left in sudden darkness, as the power is cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officers around Witwer reach for their maglite flashlights.  The Search and Command room suddenly looks exceedingly vulnerable. A technician calls out from the darkness

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, air -emergency generators will kick on in five seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The green glow from a roomful of wristwatches makes the r seem alive with fireflies.  Five seconds go by.  Then ten more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explanation, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, sir.  It seems ... he got the generators, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long moment of silence.  And then Witwer begin to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is utterly dark and silent.  The silence is brok by the SOUND of something rolling across the floor.  Some speaks, probably the guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An explosion of light fills the room in STROBE-LIKE blast And leaping through the light is ANDERSON.  The temporari blinded guard and technicians have dropped to their knees Anderson stun guns them quickly. The strobes fade, and Anderson sets a zirc-flare on the f We see that the enzyme is wearing off -- his facial featu are returning to normal. He is oblivious to the Precogs in their chairs.  It is th equipment he is after. Through the observation window we see ENNIS PAGE watching horror as Anderson severs the light cables connecting the Precog helmets to the mainframe. Anderson aims a sonic blast at the observation window, bl it out and knocking Page unconscious.  Then he reaches in the room and destroys the mainframe itself with a series blasts. Anderson is so intent on destruction he does not sense a PRESENCE behind him.  Perhaps it is because the movement so completely devoid of malice it is beyond detection. A HAND, the fingers pale and slender, reaches out and tak hold of his hand. Anderson whirls around, weapon out.  And there before him is the FEMALE Precog.  He looks at her, then beyond her t the other Precogs who are lolling in semiconsciousness in their chairs. Her helmet is off.  She is young, but her close-cropped h is silver white.  And when she speaks, her voice is like wind whispering through time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save us, Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson can feel the seconds ticking away, his carefully planned operation interrupted in an unfathomable way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grips his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is beyond pitiful, this frail little woman, pleading. And her eyes, she won't let him go.  She is beginning to weaken, to sway on her feet. A sudden realization floods over Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let me get here, didn't you? You stopped giving them information, so they couldn't track me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Precog female is fading fast.  She tries to reach out for him and her legs give way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what can Anderson do but catch her before she falls? What can he do but throw her over his shoulder, and in th fading light of the flare, make a run for freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa has been staring at the judge's monitor and the tv s for over an hour.  The two versions of Anderson murdering Witwer play over and over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wearily, to herself) Help me, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hits freeze-frame on the judge's monitor, at a moment during his confrontation with Witwer when Anderson's FACE fills the screen. Lisa looks with deep urgency into her husband's eyes. And it is his EYES, finally, that tell her everything.  L hand rises to her open mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She keeps the image on freeze-frame, and turns and looks the tv, which shows Precrime's disc over and over, the 1- number scrolling along the bottom. When the same close-up of Anderson flashes onto the tv sc she leans close to it and squints. Anderson stares right back at her.  And for the first tim Lisa sees that the tapes are not exactly identical.  His eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now they're brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time in days she allows herself a small smi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Power has been restored to Precrime Headquarters.  Witwer walks slowly through the ruins of the Chamber.  EMT teams work on Ennis Page and the other dazed personnel Anderson has left in his wake. Technicians cluster around the two remaining Precogs, the brothers.  Their eyes are closed and they are limp.  Thei lips move soundlessly as if in conversation with each oth Lieutenant Glaser is with him, but when Witwer speaks it almost to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't the Precogs know he was coming to do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant has no reply.  Witwer runs both hands thro his hair.  It has begun to wear him down, the ticking of clock ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next time he shows up it'll be to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't let that happen, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer takes in the chaotic scene around him, then gives Lieutenant a withering look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the Lieutenant tries to speak to him, Witwer walks a and goes over to the technicians working on the Precogs. stares at the Precogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a technician) When can we get these things operational?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're a hive mind, sir.  It takes three for their predictive abilities to be fully operational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which Witwer does not want to hear.  Witwer leans very cl to the technician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These two are all I have to find the man who is about to murder me.  Hook them up, and flood them with whatever kind of fucking chemicals you have to.  They are a machine, and I need that machine at my disposal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Precogs's lips stop for a microsecond, and then begin their silent movements again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis Page is a man unglued.  He sits on a tidy little so in a tidy 1950's style living room.  But his movements ha become untidy.  He puts a very tiny pill on his tongue. When he drinks from a glass of water, it dribbles down hi chin onto his shirt.  Not like Ennis, at all. When his doorbell RINGS, he slowly looks up, then looks d at the floor again.  He doesn't answer it.  It RINGS some more. And then Lisa is standing there before him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your IdentiScan is off, Ennis.  I could just walk in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot.  To turn it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't look surprised to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances at the bubble pack of pills on the table besi him, three gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unexpectedly, tears well up in Ennis's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He took one of my babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's desperate, Ennis.  He had to. (beat) We have to help him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa holds the Precog disc in front of his eyes.  He clos them against the sight, as if it were an evil talisman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a fake Ennis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis's eyes open again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the first disc.  You delivered it to Director Anderson.  He reviewed it.  And then he stole it, and went on the run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis tries to think through his fear and haze.  His word slur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I delivered ... a fake .. to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he thought it was real, and ran with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pills, his tidy world coming apart -- Ennis is losing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour later, you delivered a second disc of the same event.  Witwer reviewed it.  It was real.  (Beat) How do I know this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis just wants her to go away.  He wants it all to go a Tears stream down his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Director Anderson had his eyes changed.  They were blue.  Now he has brown ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis is sliding away.  Lisa takes hold of him.  Makes hi listen, dammit.  She points to the disc in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This disc, the fake one, shows a blueeyed Anderson murdering Witwer two days from now.  He doesn't have blue eyes anymore.  The person who faked this disc had no idea he would change his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen!  But the second disc has to be real, because he has brown eyes when he murders Witwer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Somebody tried to frame him with a fake.  And somehow it all became real. Why, Ennis?  How could this happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis gives her a look that's on the other side of comprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You handle the discs.  How did a fake one get delivered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis's eyes roll back into his head. PAGE Coffee ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want-- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spilled coffee everywhere ... Everywhere ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What coffee?  What are you -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Ennis sags unconscious.  She shakes him hard, even sl him, but Ennis is out.  She lets him drop down on the sof From outside the house, somewhere high in the clouds, com the WHINE of a hovercraft. Lisa looks once more at Ennis, then gets out of there

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, dreary room, invisible with insignificance.  Whi is just the kind of room you want if you've stolen a Prec The female Precog lies on a cot.  Anderson sits on a meta folding chair watching her. Her eyes slowly open and look at him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brothers aren't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't even look around.  You knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) We can sense each other.  You must save

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson cuts her off with a curt shake of his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop.  I saved You.  It was the best I could do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns away and looks at the yellowing paper on the wa There is a fading pink cabbage rose.  She traces the outl of it with her thin finger. She turns back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is deeply eerie for him, chatting with a Precog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going to do with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes grow very serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name me, Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a name.  I've never had one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson rises, moves around the small room.  He is shame embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me. (beat) Listen to me ... Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is heartrendingly touching, the smile she gives him wh she faces him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose.  They shifted your precognition so you would locate me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Yes.  And it hurt us, physically. Did you know that?  The helmets, the controls.  It hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (guiltily) I didn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a long moment he can't say anything.  But there are t he needs to understand ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they shifted you to find me, you didn't reveal everything.  That I was going to break into Precrime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw our chance.  You would need to shut us down, you would have to come.  We wanted you to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used me -- to save you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been used all my life, Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson can't meet her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one cared that we were human. From a human mother.  Taken at birth. Hooked to machines. (beat) We have been alive, Anderson. Enslaved, for the greater good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her words are unbearable, for both of them.  She traces t outline of the wallpaper rose again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now I have a name.  And I know the man who has named - me will not allow me to be enslaved again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson looks at her, then goes to the window, carefully watches the street below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose.  What's going to happen to us? Can you see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm weak.  And away from my brothers. I see glimpses and hints of things nearby.  But it's all ... scattered. (beat) I'm tired of the future, Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lies on the bed, watching as Anderson comes back to h He sits carefully on the side of her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then be reaches out, and gently touches her cheek

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't know I was going to do that, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is almost too overwhelmed to speak

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Oh, Anderson.  It was lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now it is Anderson who is overwhelmed

dialogues.speaker: INT. ENNIS PAGE'S HOUSE DAWN
dialogues.text: If he were not already dead, it would've killed Ennis Pag to see the state of his living room.  Precrime officers everywhere.  Blood on the rug.  A gun beside the sofa. Witwer stands in the corner of the room witching the Coro crab walk Page's body.  It WHIRS and CLICKS as it probes takes samples from various sites. The holographic doctor waits patiently as the Coroner cra makes its determinations. Lieutenant Glaser talks quietly to Witwer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else could it've been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crab probes the ragged hole in Page's head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabbed a Precog so he could commit an undetected murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Page worshipped the system.  He fell apart.  Shot himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer doesn't say anything.  He just stares at the body crab finishes.  The holographic doctor unfolds his arms a turns his head to Witwer.  He is only a computer interfac but even so, it seems as if there is surprise in his digitalized voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Director Witwer.  This event is a positive homicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) A mortal wound was generated by a .38 calibre bullet delivered to the left occipital portion of the anterior skull, on June 16th, 2040, at 1:24 am, Eastern Standard Time.  A Phase Two Investigation is in order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one says anything as the holographic doctor dematerial and the Coroner crab walks across the floor and puts itse back in its box. At last, someone moves.  It is Witwer.  He lifts his arm, pulls back his shirtsleeve, and stares long and hard at h watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lisa sits biting her lip as Witwer watches two monitors p the two versions of Anderson's murder of Witwer.  Lisa po

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches down and freezes on a close-up of Anderson on the two monitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the left monitor Anderson has blue eyes, on the right has brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one on the left, the first disc -it's a fake.  He doesn't have blue eyes anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer stares for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the Precogs predict the infallible truth.  They don't emit fake discs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now Lisa smiles.  She has set her lawyerly mind to th solution.  It is her moment .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.  You can't tamper with the Precogs, induce them to make fakes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) But that doesn't mean someone couldn't have made a fake disc on their own and inserted it into the delivery system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The simplicity of it is inconceivable.  Witwer speaks carefully, trying to process it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bypass the Precogs and slip a fake disc in with that day's real ones...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) We're all programmed to believe anything we see on a Precog disc. The system has never been wrong ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer stares at the proof before him.  -- the different colored eyes of Anderson.  He ejects both discs and holds them in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to call off the hunt.  He was set up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer looks at the two discs he is holding

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long beat) It's gone too far, Lisa She shakes her head, shocked at his response

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was set up!  You both were.  If Paul kills you, you're both out of the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wants us out?  Of what picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Ed. Stop this thing!  And then we can investigate Witwer's mouth opens and closes.  He tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ennis Page was murdered last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blood drains from Lisa's face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything points to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he is.  A murderer ... and a future murderer. (beat) Lisa.  What does it matter that the first disc is a fake ... if the second one's real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witwer's hands close tight on the discs.  Lisa stands the motionless.  Then she turns, and leaves his office, abrup He watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose sits in a chair near the window.  She is chewing lig on a cracker.  Her face shows wonder -- at the cracker's texture and taste.  She holds it up and admires its shape Anderson's mood is less wondrous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose.  Listen to me.  I'm going to leave you here.  I have to keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You must save my brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's impossible.  There's no time. I've done what I can do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose waits for him to finish.  She looks out the window a the street scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, Anderson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does, reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see that boy in the blue hat walking with his mother? (beat) In sixty seconds he will walk beneath those workers installing a window on the tenth floor of that building.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOY AND THE WORKERS
dialogues.text: Two men struggle to lift a large window in place.  Way be the little boy in the blue hat walks on along the sidewal holding his mother's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll drop the window, killing him.  It is impossible to save him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson turns to her, shocked And then he runs for the d hurls it open, and disappears down the hall. Rose listens to his FOOTSTEPS crashing down the stairs EXT. THE STREET. Even as Anderson rushes out of the boarding house, the WO have lost their grip on the window. The little BOY in the blue hat and his MOTHER walk unwitt toward disaster.  They do not appear to hear the MEN'S cr The WINDOW falls end over end above the boy's head.  The sunlight sparks off of the glass, so that from a distance looks like a star falling from the sky. A WOMAN across the street sees what is happening, and cri out. But what Anderson does is run.  He runs faster and harder than humanly possible.  He does not care if he is recogni or hit by a passing taxi.  He is going to get to that boy He has to get to that boy ... ANDERSON rams the BOY from behind just as the corner of t window frame kisses the boy's blue hat.  He knocks the bo to safety as glass and metal SMASH into the sidewalk. The mother does not even have time to scream.  She is on ground, stunned, But Anderson has saved the boy. He rolls away, and gets to his feet.  Before anyone can p together what has happened, Anderson has ducked into an a and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson enters the room again, out of breath, some small cuts on his face and hands.  He stands across the room st at Rose. Rose considers him.  When she speaks her voice is near an distant at the same time.  For Anderson, it is as if the words are coming from a place inside his own head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was impossible to save that boy -- but you did, Anderson.  It's in you.  It's what you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson sits on the floor and leans back wearily against wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew it wasn't impossible.  That I'd get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose reveals nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
